Posts.Content: I think I need to go through a PT session. I can hold all night, though I am up at least 4-5 times to go. During the day I wear a pad. I just get an occasional little spurt, often for no reason--say getting up quickly from my desk. Thought I was controlling it, but obviously not.
Posts.Title: Physical Therapy regimen with Kegels

Posts.Title: Physical Therapy regimen with Kegels

Posts.Content: Would love to hear from other gay guys. I am 61, been without a partner for about 5 years, was still hoping to find one. Leaning toward just having the prostate removed. Go in for a bone scan tomorrow. But scared about the future. Funny, death doesn't scare me, but the thought of never being able to have/enjoy sex does. Seems my prostate has already shut down--I've stopped ejaculating already. Give me some hope guys.
Posts.Title: Gay, single and newly diagnosed with prostate cancer.

Posts.Content: Found out today that I am T2--the cancer is palpable. Also found out that the cancer is far enough along that the nerves controlling erectile function on the right side will most likely be removed if I choose the surgical procedure, which I am leaning towards today. I know in my heart that I just want the cancer out of me, but it's my head that gives me trouble. ;=)

Posts.Title: Gay, single and newly diagnosed with prostate cancer.

Posts.Content: Thanks for the info so far. PSA 7. Adenocarcinoma, highest Gleason score 7 of 10 (3+4) involving both sides of prostate. Tumore involves 8 of 14 cores. Greatest linear dimension of tumor 0.7 cm. Does that make sense. I've heard something about a "T" score, don't know what that means. Meeting with surgeon tomorrow. Bone scan on Wednesday.

Posts.Title: Gay, single and newly diagnosed with prostate cancer.

Posts.Content: Yes, terrifying. Yes, bad experience. Probably worth having a medical review board double-check to be sure all procedures were followed correctly. There is a risk with all surgical procedures. I had to sign a form that said that I acknowledged that one of the possible outcomes was death. On the other, hand, a biopsy confirmed that I did, indeed, have cancer, and ultimately saved my life. Do I miss having an erection, sure, but there is more to my life than just that. I think I can still enjoy another 20-25 years without one--and I've been given the option of a technique that would allow me to create erections at will, but it's just not worth it to me. One year after surgery, life is great and I've have even found a partner that accepts for what I have, not for what I don't have.
Posts.Title: Never again!

Posts.Title: Surviving prostate cancer

Posts.Content: I just wanted to share that I just celebrated my 6th anniversary of the removal of my cancerous prostate. I am alive and well and enjoying life and cancer free. I got married in December, 2015, and retired in 2016. Travelling a lot, and ticking off items on my bucket list. Cruising to Alaska with my husband in August. For all of you who are going through what I went through six years ago, I wish you all the best. Surround yourself with positive people, pray if you believe in a higher power, read everything you can, ask every question you have, and know that there can be a wonderful life ahead of you on the other side of surgery! Godspeed on your journey! Adam

Posts.Title: Surviving prostate cancer

Posts.Content: I am scheduled for surgery on the 27th of February. I feel like I don't know what to expect immediately after coming home. I know that a catheter will be involved for the first week. How did you deal with it? And I mean I want the nitty gritty. How did you sleep? How did you deal with the catheter. Did you have pajamas? Could you walk around? How soon? Sitting up? Watching TV? Pain? Pain management. Etc., etc. etc. How did you find out this information? From trial or error? Urologist office? Surgeon's office? I am not getting any info from anywhere, but not sure where and from whom I should? Or is it just too early? Thanks!
Posts.Title: Da Vinci robotic prostatectomy recovery--the first weeks after surgery--advice wanted

Posts.Content: I was reading my morning meditations today and realized that 3 years ago today, I was in the hospital, recovering from my prostate cancer surgery. I know that when I was first diagnosed I was full of fear. I turned to this forum for advice and re-assurance. So glad that I did! I just want to share that my life is great. No sign of any return of cancer. PSA levels are negligible. Looking forward to a pleasant retirement in about a year. For newbies, get as much information as you can. Read books, talk to doctors, consult friends, share your concerns on this forum, it all helps! Best wishes on your journey. Adam
Posts.Title: Post Robotic Prostate Cancer Surgery - 3 years later
